context: [4] Cytofluorometric analysis of these cells revealed a significant activation of the reporter gene by TNF-Î± and H2O2, and the extent of activation was a function of the concentrations used. [5] The TNF-Î±-induced activation of the NF-ÎºB-dependent reporter gene was significantly decreased in the presence of 500 Î¼m SNAP (Fig.5), corroborating the findings obtained in the NF-ÎºB binding assay. [6] The inhibitory activity of SNAP on the TNF-Î±-induced activation of the NF-ÎºB-dependent reporter gene was significantly rescued by stimulation with 200 Î¼m exogenous H2O2 (Fig. 5). [7] These data confirm the inhibitory effect of nitric oxide on the H2O2-dependent activation of NF-ÎºB in TNF-Î±-treated AD10 cells. [8] We also noticed that untreated AD10 cells were able to maintain basal levels of NF-ÎºB activation that were not inhibited by treatment with nitric oxide, corroborating the findings observed in the binding assay in Fig. 3. [1] Effect of NO on the TNF -Î±-dependent activation of NF-ÎºB. [2] Transiently transfected AD10 cells with the NF-ÎºB/2EGFP reporter vector were stimulated with TNF-Î± (10 and 100 units/ml) for 2â€“3 h in the presence or absence of the NO donor SNAP (500 Î¼m).

llm_generation.summary: In this context, nitric oxide (NO) is shown to inhibit the TNF-α-induced activation of the NF-κB-dependent reporter gene in AD10 cells. The presence of the NO donor SNAP significantly decreased the activation caused by TNF-α, indicating a regulatory role of nitric oxide in modulating the inflammatory response mediated by TNF-α. This suggests a direct interaction where nitric oxide acts as a negative regulator of TNF-α signaling pathways.
llm_generation.reason: The score of 4 reflects a significant connection between nitric oxide and the TNF gene, as the data demonstrates a clear inhibitory effect of nitric oxide on TNF-α-induced gene activation, supported by experimental evidence.
